docs.snippet: WASHINGTON, Dec. 4. -- Exports of American merchandise were larger in October to twenty-eight of our fifty principal foreign markets, reaching a total of $206,351,871, figures of the Commerce Department showed today. This was $14,661,702 more than...
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 4. -- Exports of American merchandise were larger in October to twenty-eight of our fifty principal foreign markets, reaching a total of $206,351,871, figures of the Commerce Department showed today. This was $14,661,702 more than for the preceding month and $13,283,000 more than for October last year.

headline.main: EXPORTS LARGER TO 28 COUNTRIES; Our October Total of $206,351,871 Was $13,283,000 Above Same Month in 1933. $469,598,096 GAIN IN 1934 Japan, With Heavy Buying, Displaced Canada as Second Best Customer -- British Led.

docs.snippet: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7. -- The State Department, in a note delivered to the League of Nations today by Prentiss Gilbert, American Consul in Geneva, accepted the League's invitation that the United States be represented on the neutral supervisory...
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7. -- The State Department, in a note delivered to the League of Nations today by Prentiss Gilbert, American Consul in Geneva, accepted the League's invitation that the United States be represented on the neutral supervisory commission which it is planned to convene in Buenos Aires to assure that neutrality is preserved after Bolivia and Paraguay have agreed to an armistice in the Chaco warfare.
docs.abstract: U S accepts place in supervisory group at Buenos Aires to assure that neutrality is preserved after disputants agree on armistice; U S rejects seat at Geneva; members of neutrality comm

headline.main: U.S. AGREES TO AID LEAGUE IN CHACO; Accepts Place in Supervisory Group at Buenos Aires With a Reservation. REJECTS SEAT AT GENEVA But Washington Offers to Keep in 'Informal Contact' With Body Arranging Peace Terms.

byline.original: Special to THE NEW YORK TIMES

docs.snippet: Weakness in the English pound and the Scandinavians, while the French franc was firm, stood out in contrast in last week's trading in the foreign currencies. Weakness in sterling emanated abroad, and was carried further in the trading here. The belga...
docs.lead_paragraph: Weakness in the English pound and the Scandinavians, while the French franc was firm, stood out in contrast in last week's trading in the foreign currencies. Weakness in sterling emanated abroad, and was carried further in the trading here. The belga and guilder were unchanged on the week, but the mark and Swiss franc were slightly lower. Mid-Europeans ruled steady, the Far Easterns irregular.

headline.main: FOREIGN EXCHANGE RATES; WEEK ENDED DEC. 8, 1934.
